intro.title: When Someone Dies: Your First Steps
intro.subtitle: Losing someone you love brings profound changes to your life. While the immediate shock may have passed, there are still many practical matters to address. This guide provides detailed information to help you navigate the process with clarity and confidence.

medical_certification.title: Medical Certification and the Medical Examiner
medical_certification.description: Since September 2024, the death certification process follows these steps:
steps: Initial Certification: The doctor who cared for your loved one completes a Medical Certificate of Cause of Death
Medical Examiner Review: A second doctor reviews the death using medical records
Family Consultation: The Medical Examiner will contact you to discuss their findings and address any questions about your loved one's care
Final Approval: Once satisfied, the Medical Examiner sends the information to the Registrar
medical_certification.note: This process ensures thoroughness while respecting your need to proceed with funeral arrangements.

registration.title: Registering the Death
registration.description: Registration must occur within five days unless the Coroner is involved. This important legal step allows you to:
benefits: Begin settling your loved one's affairs

who_can_register.title: Who can register a death:
list: The occupier of the premises where death occurred

documents.title: Documents you'll receive:
list: Death certificates (£12 each) – order several as you'll need them for banks, insurance, and other institutions
Certificate for burial or cremation (sent electronically to funeral directors)
Information about the Tell Us Once service

tell_us_once.title: The Tell Us Once Service
tell_us_once.description: This free government service simplifies notifying multiple departments about the death. One notification covers:
tell_us_once.note: The Registrar will provide you with a unique reference number to access this service online or by phone.

coroner.title: When the Coroner is Involved
circumstances: The cause of death is unclear
The person wasn't seen by a doctor during their final illness
There are concerns about the circumstances

what_to_expect.title: What to expect:
list: The Coroner's involvement is routine in these circumstances
They may order a post-mortem to determine cause of death
You'll be kept informed throughout the process
Funeral arrangements can usually proceed once initial investigations are complete
In rare cases requiring an inquest, we'll guide you through the extended timeline
